intro: Ophrys apifera var. quintianensis, commonly known as the bee orchid, is a striking member of the Orchidaceae family native to the Mediterranean region. This plant is characterized by its unique floral morphology, with its lip resembling a bee, which plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils and thrives in sunny, open habitats. Its flowers bloom from late spring to early summer, producing a vibrant display of yellow and brown hues. Ophrys apifera var. quintianensis is known for its specialized relationship with specific pollinators, particularly male bees, which are deceived into attempting to mate with the flower.
